revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-28 13:27:49.000000000', 'message': "Do not check available space for image convertion on block devices

Some backends like SolidFire mount volumes as block devices. In such case
cinder can't figure out if there enough space to convert image. We can
skip a check in this case, so volume backend will fail later during
image to volume upload.

This case was mentioned in the comments for
Ie5eba32f92eb1740554bfc44baf612e326d6fde5 change request.

Change-Id: I3c139cce9e3fed967fc76b6e5cb24267da473de8
Related-Bug: #1756425
"}]
commit_message:
Do not check available space for image convertion on block devices

Some backends like SolidFire mount volumes as block devices. In such case
cinder can't figure out if there enough space to convert image. We can
skip a check in this case, so volume backend will fail later during
image to volume upload.

This case was mentioned in the comments for
Ie5eba32f92eb1740554bfc44baf612e326d6fde5 change request.

Change-Id: I3c139cce9e3fed967fc76b6e5cb24267da473de8
Related-Bug: #1756425

commit_message:
Use become when testing image presence

Become is used on the play that builds the image, so it's possible we might not
be able to access it without root privileges.

Change-Id: I62d45e937b69215890fc88f1cd59c97319558994

[{'created': '2019-01-28 15:43:23.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for passing optional ``requested_roles`` attribute

When passing ``requested_roles`` down the ``identity-service``

Useful for charm authors implementing charms with specific role

Closes-Bug: #1813602

commit_message:
Add support for passing optional ``requested_roles`` attribute

When passing ``requested_roles`` down the ``identity-service``
relation the Keystone charm will create the listed roles for you.

Useful for charm authors implementing charms with specific role
requirements.

Change-Id: I7c1eedb1e78ffc53ac3e0df81f6b52358dd8dfa5
Closes-Bug: #1813602

commit_message:
Drop function parameter from launch()

The parameter is not used and when calling the console-script
"monasca-api" (usually installed in /usr/bin on package
installations), currently it fails with:

  TypeError: launch() takes exactly 1 argument (0 given)

This is now fixed.

Change-Id: I57b6e7f0b8bac50da4b3ec1acdea489ca5c7186f
Story: 2004880
Task: 29159

commit_message:
Use the canonical URL for repositories (git.openstack.org)

- When the URL refers to cloning or using git repositories, use the
  cloning URL (https://git.openstack.org/<namespace>/<project>)
- When the URL refers to the browsable version of the repository, point to
  the cgit frontend (https://git.openstack.org/cgit/<namespace>/<project>)

Change-Id: Iaeaa153a05aa85b9cf7451ae3c28aec56722222c

[{'created': '2017-07-31 16:46:27.000000000', 'message': 'Ignore exceptions getting FloatingIP dependencies

When calculating the dependencies for a FloatingIP resource, we make
REST calls to Neutron. If this call fails then we will stop looking for
implicit dependencies for that resource. (Prior to the fix for bug
1554625, it would have broken the stack altogether.)

This change ignores any errors that occur while making the client call,
so that any other implicit dependencies can potentially still be
discovered.

Closes-Bug: #1442121

commit_message:
Ignore exceptions getting FloatingIP dependencies

When calculating the dependencies for a FloatingIP resource, we make
REST calls to Neutron. If this call fails then we will stop looking for
implicit dependencies for that resource. (Prior to the fix for bug
1554625, it would have broken the stack altogether.)

This change ignores any errors that occur while making the client call,
so that any other implicit dependencies can potentially still be
discovered.

Change-Id: Ic9220041e7bf85b4388ad283082833cfbdb6c76a
Story: #1442121
Task: 16622

subject: Use utf8mb4 for MySQL like databases
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6593, 'name': 'Dirk Mueller', 'email': 'dirk@dmllr.de', 'username': 'dmllr'}, {'_account_id': 7118, 'name': 'Ian Wienand', 'email': 'iwienand@redhat.com', 'username': 'iwienand'}, {'_account_id': 10118, 'name': 'IBM PowerKVM CI', 'email': 'kvmpower@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'powerkvm', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 10385, 'name': 'Citrix XenServer CI', 'username': 'citrix_xenserver_ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 14595, 'name': 'z Systems KVM', 'email': 'zkvm-ci@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'ibm-zkvm-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2017-11-04 18:34:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-11-07 00:36:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

What do i know about the details of this?  not much ...

but it seems like it's been fairly explicitly decided to only support 3-byte unicode and nova, at least, may very well have field lengths that can cause problems with this [1]?  i'd personally want to see weigh in from people who know about this that it's safe...   

my -1 is mostly that i'd like to see it explained why this is safe

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova-specs/tree/specs/kilo/implemented/relax-resource-name-restrictions.rst"}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2017-11-07 01:00:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Yeah, it looks like it causes failures:

nCREATE TABLE migrate_version (\n\trepository_id VARCHAR(250) NOT NULL, \n\trepository_path TEXT, \n\tversion INTEGER, \n\tPRIMARY KEY (repository_id)\n)\n\n']\x1b[00m: InternalError: (1071, u'Specified key was too long; max key length is 767 bytes')"}, {'account_id': 6593, 'date': '2019-01-29 06:20:24.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

No time for this atm'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-04 18:34:21.000000000', 'message': 'Use utf8mb4 for MySQL like databases

the utf8 encoding in MySQL/MariaDB only supports codepoints up to 3
bytes. For full unicode support we need utf8mb4. There are more
reasons other than not being able to store U+1F4A9 PILE OF POO
correctly, see https://mathiasbynens.be/notes/mysql-utf8mb4

Change-Id: I5b384586b5d9e62f6fadde622f80b316bbbdbd1d
'}]
commit_message:
Use utf8mb4 for MySQL like databases

the utf8 encoding in MySQL/MariaDB only supports codepoints up to 3
bytes. For full unicode support we need utf8mb4. There are more
reasons other than not being able to store U+1F4A9 PILE OF POO
correctly, see https://mathiasbynens.be/notes/mysql-utf8mb4

Change-Id: I5b384586b5d9e62f6fadde622f80b316bbbdbd1d

commit_message:
Include the Fedora macros when RHEL/CentOS is > 7

Some of the Fedora macros are relevant to RHEL 8, such as those
related to Python 3. We should include them in the package for those
cases.

Change-Id: Id41911119d47def7276311e8e1dcf8fc1ec8004f

commit_message:
Update parameters for cinder's Netapp backend

Update THT to align with puppet-tripleo changes made in [1]
- Add new CinderNetappPoolNameSearchPattern parameter
- Deprecate CinderNetappStoragePools parameter
- Remove previously deprecated CinderNetappEseriesHostType parameter

[1] https://review.openstack.org/570406

Fix relative path in file the sample-env-generator uses to generate
environments/storage/cinder-netapp-config.yaml.

Change-Id: I813ca60eb5ce9e008e1b72e88d83709d3125676f

subject: Remove L3 and DHCP dependency for sriov_agent
messages:
[{'account_id': 27499, 'date': '2019-01-29 00:04:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-01-29 00:04:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-01-29 00:05:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2019-01-29 03:35:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add "Report device data to cyborg"

1. Load drivers with stevedore
2. Now update_usage just do the discover, add report data when
   conductor api ready.

Change-Id: Ia813c5a8dd8f29ce689204e52b6e1f691633f5fc

commit_message:
Correct default policy_file in the sample config

When the sample config is generated, the policy_file default value
specified by oslo.policy is showing up, not the default value that
Cinder is using.  Correct this by enhancing the function specified
for cinder in the oslo.config.opts.defaults entry point.

This patch exposed Bug #1807184 in oslo.policy.  The requirements
and lower-constraints changes on this patch bump the minimum
version of oslo.policy we use to include the fix (1.44.1).  This
version was already included in upper-constraints by Change
I50bb9d48106376f5baaafae372492c0744182da2.

Change-Id: Ic28d660a9d876139f47f98cf1024a30b005cd0e0
Closes-bug: #1807071

commit_message:
Add option to place etcd data dir on RAM disk

Seems like for etcd-heavy services like Kubernetes, the fsync
performance of gate VM's are too low [1]. This commit implements an
option to put etcd data directory on RAM disk (tmpfs) to work this
around.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-January/001849.html

Change-Id: I5a17099cb9d6941b1a009dc82daefd2c7946d892

plugin.

[{'created': '2018-05-30 16:26:41.000000000', 'message': "Increase limit for RandomString test_overlapping_classes

I've seen two gate failures, with means of 12.80 and 12.85. With the
previous bug 1757300 present the mean would have been around 26, so
increasing the limit to 13.3 is pretty safe.

Change-Id: Ifc8badbdfef423a58f6378a28ddc5c5b90853c56
"}]
commit_message:
Increase limit for RandomString test_overlapping_classes

I've seen two gate failures, with means of 12.80 and 12.85. With the
previous bug 1757300 present the mean would have been around 26, so
increasing the limit to 13.3 is pretty safe.

Change-Id: Ifc8badbdfef423a58f6378a28ddc5c5b90853c56

> > @Hongbin,
 > >
 > > I think keeping track of the infra container is good.
 > > But what i think is, it is going to make the Container table size
 > > double, that may hamper other operations on table. What about
 > > creating another table for it and storing the id of it in
 > container
 > > table as foreign key? Thoughts?
 > 
 > @PradeepÔºå@HongbinÔºå
 > 
 > Currently, I save the container and its infra_container in the same
 > table. A filter is added in the list_containers(zun/db/sqlalchemy/api.py),
 > so the user experience should be the same as before.

@Shengqin,

I think @Pradeep gave a good suggestion on this. I have been thinking it for a while and I think having a dedicated table for sandbox is a better option. Doing this will not only reduce the table size, but also give us flexibility to evolve the sandbox schema independently. Right now, we can reuse the container schema for sandbox, but that might not be true in the future. For example, there is a proposed idea to implement "sandbox" as a nova instance (related to the container-in-vm bp [1]). This idea won't be easily implemented if the sandbox and container are mixed together. Therefore, I like the idea of separating these two tables.

I will update the BP for the details. Please check it out after.

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/zun/+spec/vm-as-container-host'}, {'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2017-06-06 03:04:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-06-06 04:01:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

commit_message:
Persist infra container in DB

1. Add a field infra_container_id into the container table.
   It points to the uuid of its sandbox container.
2. Create a new table for storing sandbox.
3. The user experience should be the same as before.

Change-Id: I09e518d9978a0acea620eeb8d1aafdfbc481006f
Implements: blueprint infra-container-in-db

(3 comments)

Thanks for fixing the gates; looks like remaining failures are unrelated. But what's missing is a reno to just say what this accomplishes, like:

   Patrole will check the deprecated policy rule (if applicable) alongside the current policy rule, until support for system token authorization is implemented in Tempest and Patrole.

Also adds Keystone role expansion (admin implies member implies reader).

Something like that."}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-26 00:06:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

(2 comments)

Felipe, thank you. I will add a reno'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-26 01:49:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18:

Felipe, I don't agree with this sentence: until support for system token authorization is implemented

The problem is that the oslo.policy will work with default and deprecated rules and there can be a situation, when the default rule is `role:reader` and deprecated is `role:member`. So in this case Patrole checks only default rule against member and the result will be no allowed, but when Patrole makes an action and don't get an error, because oslo.policy allows that action for member. So we will get OverPermission. My opinion, we always should use deprecated rules."}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-26 01:51:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

We just need to figure out how to work with system_scope, then default rule will be applied, but deprecated rule should be used too.'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-26 02:06:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-26 03:41:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

recheck please'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2019-01-28 01:06:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

> Felipe, I don't agree with this sentence: until support for system
 > token authorization is implemented
 > 
 > The problem is that the oslo.policy will work with default and
 > deprecated rules and there can be a situation, when the default
 > rule is `role:reader` and deprecated is `role:member`. So in this
 > case Patrole checks only default rule against member and the result
 > will be no allowed, but when Patrole makes an action and don't get
 > an error, because oslo.policy allows that action for member. So we
 > will get OverPermission. My opinion, we always should use
 > deprecated rules.

Yes, oslo.policy appears to enforce both deprecated and default for backwards compatibility: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/b9fd10e2612f26c93d49c168a0408aba6d20e5bf/oslo_policy/policy.py#L691

But the problem with testing both at the same time in Patrole is that if you fail the default but pass the deprecated then the test will pass. But as a testing framework I think we should be more interested in testing the default, not the deprecated.

Thus I think it makes sense to introduce a Patrole config option like "validate_deprecated_rules", that, if true, does the check you currently introduced. Otherwise, if false, it only validates the default.'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-28 02:22:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 19:

> But the problem with testing both at the same time in Patrole is
 > that if you fail the default but pass the deprecated then the test
 > will pass.

But If we will check only default, and the policy_authority tells us that the action is not allowed, then we will get OverPermission, like now, because oslo.policy will allow that action'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-28 02:24:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 19:

I'm ok with check_deprecated_rules option, will update the patch"}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-28 02:50:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2019-01-28 04:20:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 20: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

LGTM. Only thing is that I think there's not unit test to validate the deprecated rule logic but I'm OK to add that separately as this unblocks the gate which is the most important thing. Great job."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 04:59:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 05:02:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 05:22:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

> > Felipe, I don't agree with this sentence: until support for
 > system
 > > token authorization is implemented
 > >
 > > The problem is that the oslo.policy will work with default and
 > > deprecated rules and there can be a situation, when the default
 > > rule is `role:reader` and deprecated is `role:member`. So in this
 > > case Patrole checks only default rule against member and the
 > result
 > > will be no allowed, but when Patrole makes an action and don't
 > get
 > > an error, because oslo.policy allows that action for member. So
 > we
 > > will get OverPermission. My opinion, we always should use
 > > deprecated rules.
 > 
 > Yes, oslo.policy appears to enforce both deprecated and default for
 > backwards compatibility: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/b9fd10e2612f26c93d49c168a0408aba6d20e5bf/oslo_policy/policy.py#L691
 > 
 > But the problem with testing both at the same time in Patrole is
 > that if you fail the default but pass the deprecated then the test
 > will pass. But as a testing framework I think we should be more
 > interested in testing the default, not the deprecated.
 > 
 > Thus I think it makes sense to introduce a Patrole config option
 > like "validate_deprecated_rules", that, if true, does the check you
 > currently introduced. Otherwise, if false, it only validates the
 > default.

I agree on Felipe point of testing the latest default than deprecated. deprecated will be checked while switching to new default or via stable/branch jobs where that rule/role is not deprecated. 

oslo policy will only log a warning when deprecated and default not equal so checking deprecated based on config option make sense. But I am wondering how we will decide the deprecated check and do not check based on tests ? For example when test start using new default values then we should not use deprecated values for oslo direct check. One possible way is to use fixture to set/unset new config per test. Anyways that is next thing to discuss fix.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 05:26:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 07:43:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 07:45:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Code-Review+1

fix lgtm now but only holding this for question on usage of new config option.'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-28 13:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(4 comments)

About unit tests, I will add them in follow up commit'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-28 13:55:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-28 18:33:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2019-01-28 21:33:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 23:28:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Code-Review+2

lgtm now. Thanks a lot, Sergey for fixing it, nice work. Waiting for Felipe (I am sure he still sleep late and will approve it :).'}, {'account_id': 23186, 'date': '2019-01-29 02:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Fix OverPermission exception for keystone tests

Extend the roles in `access_token` according to the implementation[0]
of the bp basic-default-roles:
    `admin` implies `member` implies `reader`
Support deprecated rules.

[0] Ie18a269e3d1075d955fe494acaf634a393c6bd7b

Change-Id: I0d0de2a20b03548a7e5dab1ee7af7b72651abcb6
Story: 2004709
Task: 28740

commit_message:
Always reset task state to None

Upon the completion of attaching/detaching network, always set the
task_state to none. This ensures the task_state is cleanup on
exception.

Change-Id: Ia664df05b13090b28be7dcfc44649954bb4c0f9d
Closes-Bug: #1812602

commit_message:
Enable ML2 baremetal by default with Ironic service

When support for routed provider networks and Ironic was
added in tripleo the mechanism driver was only enabled
for the undercloud.

Override the NeutronMechanismDrivers parameter to add
'baremetal' mech driver in the Ironic service environment.

Closes-Bug: #1812936
Change-Id: I555684541846f325c02c0fd8cb9c82ac4b8ede5b

commit_message:
Improve error message around hieradata override file

If the file specified is empty, we currently throw a generic message
about it not being in the correct format. Let's add a check to make sure
the file is not empty before attempting to parse it as yaml.

Change-Id: I702da1170484c0d10c3ae836ec3f7550975a341c
Closes-Bug: #1810436
(cherry picked from commit 8ddcc2cd145451335a90b6816c8110c65dc73998)

commit_message:
Look for parameters in parameter_groups

Look for used parameters in parameter_groups

This patch searches for parameter use in the parameter_groups section
as well and should eliminate some false positive warnings with
our validations.

Change-Id: I67c5ad2b6e865d454489702e5eb263a9508d26d2

commit_message:
rabbitmq:  Remove default post-save command for certmonger

The default command didn't work, so we need to fix that.

The script additionally copies the certificates in the right place
and instead of restarting RabbitMQ, it triggers a pem cache reload.

Related-Bug: #1811401

commit_message:
HTK: update fqdn hostname lookup to support host keys

This PS adds support for maps containing `host` for use within
the endpoint host lookup functions as well as a simple string

Change-Id: Ifddfb935bf12510a8b8fac25a4a18b4314845230
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

commit_message:
Fix issues around LDAP backed Keystone

Invite user workflow now defaults to domain_id from
the project.

Create project workflow now default to getting domain
and parent id from config.

Identity manager now has setting to flag the inability to
edit/create users, which some actions now support.

Fix an issue with email comparison when username_is_email was true.

Change-Id: I8548914e3d2283b17f3015595ea72c4c8084d7f5

commit_message:
Add CentOS support in devstack federation plugin

Modify the install_federation function for adding Shibboleth repo
and installation for CentOS in federation.sh, and also modify
uninstall_federation function for removing Shibboleth packages
when running `./unstack.sh`.

Partial-bug: #1757000

Change-Id: I8c0f63d0a4fe19eab58e7cba3c49905f35266f9d

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-25 16:24:47.000000000', 'message': 'Filter duplicated ports before radvd config generation

In some cases it is possible that in interface_list which is
passed to neutron.agent.linux.ra.DaemonMonitor when daemon
is enabling, may contains duplicated interfaces.
That leads to generate radvd config with duplicate interfaces
definition which in some versions of radvd causes crash of
daemon.

This patch adds filtering of such duplicated interfaces from this
list. Only interface with newest revision is used to generate
radvd config file.

Change-Id: I6f3386a4dd9d2570c6fb42aa9852b6d8c588df04
Closes-Bug: #1813279
'}, {'created': '2019-01-25 20:24:43.000000000', 'message': 'Filter duplicated ports before radvd config generation

In some cases it is possible that in interface_list which is
passed to neutron.agent.linux.ra.DaemonMonitor when daemon
is enabling, may contains duplicated interfaces.
That leads to generate radvd config with duplicate interfaces
definition which in some versions of radvd causes crash of
daemon.

This patch adds filtering of such duplicated interfaces from this
list. Only interface with newest revision is used to generate
radvd config file.

Change-Id: I6f3386a4dd9d2570c6fb42aa9852b6d8c588df04
Closes-Bug: #1813279
'}]
commit_message:
Filter duplicated ports before radvd config generation

In some cases it is possible that in interface_list which is
passed to neutron.agent.linux.ra.DaemonMonitor when daemon
is enabling, may contains duplicated interfaces.
That leads to generate radvd config with duplicate interfaces
definition which in some versions of radvd causes crash of
daemon.

This patch adds filtering of such duplicated interfaces from this
list. Only interface with newest revision is used to generate
radvd config file.

Change-Id: I6f3386a4dd9d2570c6fb42aa9852b6d8c588df04
Closes-Bug: #1813279

(5 comments)

Eric, while I definitely appreciate the code removal and simplification that this patch introduces, I'm extremely wary of the impact this particular patch would have on Ironic installations -- where a single nova-compute service can manage thousands of Ironic baremetal resource nodes.

I think blowing away the entire ProviderTree (cache) for these nova-compute services would cause unnecessary traffic to be generated to placement for potentially thousands of Ironic resource nodes as they are re-added to the ProviderTree when update_available_resource(nodename) is called.

Please see more comments inline...

-jay"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-11-28 23:15:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(5 comments)

Thanks for the review, Jay. To summarize the bits I think you're asking to be changed: I played with several approaches including the one you suggest, and they all wound up smelly. I picked what I thought was the cleanest one. If you feel strongly, I can rework it, but I would prefer to keep it like this. Perhaps in a fup we could do the thing I marked with (‚ô™) - though I think that would be a pretty big refactor for little value beyond deodorizing."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-01-14 23:00:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-01-15 15:03:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

(2 comments)

Not lot to add beyond what others have said, a bit of support for jay's suggestion of additional method, within.

Also, reading through this and some of the related discussion it feels like a lot of this work is being done through analysis of the code and without full confirmation of what the resource tracker etc actually do and it seems like it might be worthwhile to set up a devstack, hork a bunch of prints or writes to stderr throughout the code, and verify some of the assumptions with real world cases. I know that's icky and dirty, but there's a lot of legacy ick and dirt here.

Another option, which I'm actually a fan of, would be to merge this stuff sooner than later and let the chips fall, possibly with some bugs, and fix them as they show up.

In either case, we're trying to analyse (rather than experiment) our way to perfection and I think that's a bit of a fools errand with the compute manager."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-01-15 19:09:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-05 22:10:11.000000000', 'message': "WIP: update_from_provider_tree: fast fail, clear cache

Prior to this patch, the report client's update_from_provider_tree
method would, upon failure of any placement API call, invalidate the
cache *just* for the failing provider (and any descendants) and attempt
to continue operating on any other providers in the tree.

With this patch, we instead invalidate the whole cache and fail right
away.

In real life, since we don't yet have any implementations of sharing or
nested, this is effectively a null change.

Except: this allows us to resolve a TODO whereby we would *always*
_ensure_resource_provider (including a call to GET
/resource_providers?in_tree=$compute_rp) on every periodic. Now we can
optimize that out.

This should reduce the number of calls to placement per RT periodic by
one.

Change-Id: Ieeaad9783e0ff93377fbc6c7932618d2fac8946a
WIP: Surely some testing must be necessary here
"}, {'created': '2018-11-05 23:56:51.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Reduce calls to placement from _ensure

Prior to this patch, the report client's update_from_provider_tree
method would, upon failure of any placement API call, invalidate the
cache *just* for the failing provider (and any descendants) and attempt
to continue operating on any other providers in the tree.

With this patch, we instead invalidate the whole cache and fail right
away.

In real life, since we don't yet have any implementations of sharing or
nested, this is effectively a null change.

Except: this allows us to resolve a TODO whereby we would *always*
_ensure_resource_provider (including a call to GET
/resource_providers?in_tree=$compute_rp) on every periodic. Now we can
optimize that out.

This should reduce the number of calls to placement per RT periodic by
one.

But we need to make sure that, whenever we're bootstrapping the compute
node record (either for the first time, or because the operator deleted
the compute service and restarted it), we force that call to placement
to guarantee that the compute node resource provider is created. So we
do that by clearing the provider cache from the resource tracker if
is_new_compute_node is detected.

WIP: Tests

Change-Id: Ieeaad9783e0ff93377fbc6c7932618d2fac8946a

"}, {'created': '2018-11-29 22:56:03.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Reduce calls to placement from _ensure

WIP: I ran out of time, need to update the tests for the ufpt change
from blow-away-the-whole-cache to blow-away-the-affected-tree.

Prior to this patch, the report client's update_from_provider_tree
method would, upon failure of any placement API call, invalidate the
cache *just* for the failing provider (and any descendants) and attempt
to continue operating on any other providers in the tree.

With this patch, we instead invalidate the tree around the failing
provider and fail right away.

In real life, since we don't yet have any implementations of nested,
this would have been effectively a null change.

Except: this allows us to resolve a TODO whereby we would *always*
_ensure_resource_provider (including a call to GET
/resource_providers?in_tree=$compute_rp) on every periodic. Now we can
optimize that out.

This should reduce the number of calls to placement per RT periodic to
zero in steady state when [compute]resource_provider_association_refresh
is zero.

But we also need to make sure that, whenever we're bootstrapping the
compute node record (either for the first time, or because the operator
deleted the compute service and restarted it), we force that call to
placement to guarantee that the compute node resource provider is
created. So we do that by clearing the provider cache from the resource
tracker if is_new_compute_node is detected.

Closes-Bug: #1742467

Change-Id: Ieeaad9783e0ff93377fbc6c7932618d2fac8946a

commit_message:
Reduce calls to placement from _ensure

Prior to this patch, the report client's update_from_provider_tree
method would, upon failure of any placement API call, invalidate the
cache *just* for the failing provider (and any descendants) and attempt
to continue operating on any other providers in the tree.

With this patch, we instead invalidate the tree around the failing
provider and fail right away.

In real life, since we don't yet have any implementations of nested,
this would have been effectively a null change.

Except: this allows us to resolve a TODO whereby we would *always*
_ensure_resource_provider (including a call to GET
/resource_providers?in_tree=$compute_rp) on every periodic. Now we can
optimize that out.

This should reduce the number of calls to placement per RT periodic to
zero in steady state when [compute]resource_provider_association_refresh
is zero.

Closes-Bug: #1742467

commit_message:
Handle unbound vif plug errors on compute restart

As with change Ia963a093a1b26d90b4de2e8fc623031cf175aece, we can
sometimes cache failed port binding information which we'll see on
startup. Long term, the fix for both issues is to figure out how this is
being cached and stop that happening but for now we simply need to allow
the service to start up.

To this end, we copy the approach in the aforementioned change and
implement a translation function in os_vif_util for unbound which
will make the plug_vifs code raise VirtualInterfacePlugException which
is what the _init_instance code in ComputeManager is already handling.

This has the same caveats as that change, namely that there may be
smarter ways to do this that we should explore. However, that change
also included a note which goes someway to explaining this.

Change-Id: Iaec1f6fd12dba8b11991b7a7595593d5c8b1db50
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Related-bug: #1784579
Closes-bug: #1809136
(cherry picked from commit 1def76a1c49032d93ab6c7ee61dbbfe8e29cafca)
(cherry picked from commit bc0a5d0355311641daa87b46e311ae101f1817ad)
(cherry picked from commit 79a90d37027b7ca131218e16eaee70d6d5152206)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-19 16:44:38.000000000', 'message': 'Handle binding_failed vif plug errors on compute restart

Like change Ia584dba66affb86787e3069df19bd17b89cb5c49 which
came before, is port binding fails and we have a "binding_failed"
vif type in the info cache, we'll fail to plug vifs for an
instance on compute restart which will prevent the service
from restarting. Before the os-vif conversion code, this was
handled with VirtualInterfacePlugException but the os-vif conversion
code fails in a different way by raising a generic NovaException
because the os-vif conversion utility doesn't handle a vif_type of
"binding_failed".

To resolve this and make the os-vif flow for binding_failed behave
the same as the legacy path, we implement a translation function
in os_vif_util for binding_failed which will make the plug_vifs
code raise VirtualInterfacePlugException which is what the
_init_instance code in ComputeManager is already handling.

Admittedly this isn't the smartest thing and doesn't attempt
to recover / fix the instance networking info, but it at least
gives a more clear indication of what's wrong and lets the
nova-compute service start up. A note is left in the
_init_instance error handling that we could potentially try
to heal binding_failed vifs in _heal_instance_info_cache, but
that would need to be done in a separate change since it's more
invasive.

Change-Id: Ia963a093a1b26d90b4de2e8fc623031cf175aece
Closes-Bug: #1784579
(cherry picked from commit cdf8ba5acb7f65042af9c21fcbe1a126bd857ad0)
(cherry picked from commit a890e3d624a84d8eb0306fab580e2cec33e26bc3)
(cherry picked from commit 4827cedbc56033c2ac3caf0d7998fca6aff997d6)
'}]
commit_message:
Handle binding_failed vif plug errors on compute restart

Like change Ia584dba66affb86787e3069df19bd17b89cb5c49 which
came before, is port binding fails and we have a "binding_failed"
vif type in the info cache, we'll fail to plug vifs for an
instance on compute restart which will prevent the service
from restarting. Before the os-vif conversion code, this was
handled with VirtualInterfacePlugException but the os-vif conversion
code fails in a different way by raising a generic NovaException
because the os-vif conversion utility doesn't handle a vif_type of
"binding_failed".

To resolve this and make the os-vif flow for binding_failed behave
the same as the legacy path, we implement a translation function
in os_vif_util for binding_failed which will make the plug_vifs
code raise VirtualInterfacePlugException which is what the
_init_instance code in ComputeManager is already handling.

Admittedly this isn't the smartest thing and doesn't attempt
to recover / fix the instance networking info, but it at least
gives a more clear indication of what's wrong and lets the
nova-compute service start up. A note is left in the
_init_instance error handling that we could potentially try
to heal binding_failed vifs in _heal_instance_info_cache, but
that would need to be done in a separate change since it's more
invasive.

Change-Id: Ia963a093a1b26d90b4de2e8fc623031cf175aece
Closes-Bug: #1784579
(cherry picked from commit cdf8ba5acb7f65042af9c21fcbe1a126bd857ad0)
(cherry picked from commit a890e3d624a84d8eb0306fab580e2cec33e26bc3)
(cherry picked from commit 4827cedbc56033c2ac3caf0d7998fca6aff997d6)

commit_message:
Temporarily add opendev/base-jobs as an untrusted-project

This will cause Zuul to generate a private key, so we can bootstrap
the repo.  Later we'll add it back as a config-project.

Change-Id: Id4886ebd30825ec5361c0f7e237b27b5dd4c6abf

commit_message:
Make barbican-kmip-devstack-functional job non-voting

Currently the 'barbican-kmip-devstack-functional' keeps failing when
generating certificate for pykmip server. The error log:
http://logs.openstack.org/15/578615/4/check/barbican-kmip-devstack-functional/51fb5b9/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz#_2018-07-20_20_59_01_409

This patch makes the job not vote temporarily while someone is working
on the solution in order not to block the merge process.

Change-Id: Iabe4658d26c7600e0f59e60d7940645c3b371a6f
(cherry picked from commit e5470d8cc22eeb6fb418c0e24daa865113f99166)

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1] stestr is maintained project
to which all Openstack projects should migrate. Let's switch it then.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

This patch is heavily based on the patch submitted to Neutron at:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570008/

Change-Id: Ib6c2ae56dc933dd9c3cb39e942251f41039b800b
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Properly pass the CA to requests

We store the CA in request.cert, but it's not compatible with a cert. To
pass the CA to requests, we need to set the verify argument.

Change-Id: Id0f39e3253b1486db8ae2da3d7dc6c0fdb41062a
(cherry picked from commit 13e90a0ab5e296fb8cf21d09c666c06ed47a84c0)

[{'created': '2019-01-23 03:17:21.000000000', 'message': 'Add upgrade status check for missing root ids

Starting in Queens with the 1.28 microversion, resource_providers
table has the root_provider_id column. Older resource_providers with
no root provider id records will be online migrated when accessed
via the REST API or when the
"placement-manage db online_data_migrations" command is run during
an upgrade. This status check emits a warning if there are missing
root provider ids to remind operators to perform the data migration.

Note that normally we would not add an upgrade status check to simply
mirror an online data migration since online data migrations should
be part of deploying/upgrading placement automation. However, with
placement being freshly extracted from nova, this check serves as a
friendly reminder.

Change-Id: I503c7d4e829407175992a90002646110aa9a323f

commit_message:
Add upgrade status check for missing root ids

Starting in Queens with the 1.28 microversion, resource_providers
table has the root_provider_id column. Older resource_providers with
no root provider id records will be online migrated when accessed
via the REST API or when the
"placement-manage db online_data_migrations" command is run during
an upgrade. This status check emits a warning if there are missing
root provider ids to remind operators to perform the data migration.

Note that normally we would not add an upgrade status check to simply
mirror an online data migration since online data migrations should
be part of deploying/upgrading placement automation. However, with
placement being freshly extracted from nova, this check serves as a
friendly reminder.

Change-Id: I503c7d4e829407175992a90002646110aa9a323f

commit_message:
HTK: support a map for hostname lookups

This PS adds support for maps containing `host` for use within
the hostname lookup functions as well as a simple string.

Change-Id: I6fc5ebfb349c6581d40fe2d8723771d16ba1f9ec
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

subject: Fix keystone::client testing
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-28 15:11:07.000000000', 'message': "Fix keystone::client testing

Fixes the failing testing since the package resource in the
openstacklib::openstackclient class was changed [1].

Modules testing should *never* check names of other resources
but only the actual resources it's using, which in this case is
the openstacklib::openstackclient class and not the package.

Also takes the oppertunity to convert the testing to using
rspec-puppet-facts, the keystone modules is the only module
that is left until all modules are using rspec-puppet-facts.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/59/632459/9/check/puppet-openstack-unit-4.8-centos-7/0886361/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-01-28_13_16_02_682694

Change-Id: I4c86797fba211387a53036ce933e430daefb8f0e
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone::client testing

Fixes the failing testing since the package resource in the
openstacklib::openstackclient class was changed [1].

Modules testing should *never* check names of other resources
but only the actual resources it's using, which in this case is
the openstacklib::openstackclient class and not the package.

Also takes the oppertunity to convert the testing to using
rspec-puppet-facts, the keystone modules is the only module
that is left until all modules are using rspec-puppet-facts.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/59/632459/9/check/puppet-openstack-unit-4.8-centos-7/0886361/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-01-28_13_16_02_682694

Change-Id: I4c86797fba211387a53036ce933e430daefb8f0e

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-06 23:47:46.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Reload haproxy when certificate is renewed

Change-Id: Id409899bf04e7f9f2653e6c48cfebd0a92ca2d08
'}, {'created': '2018-12-07 08:14:03.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Reload haproxy when certificate is renewed

Change-Id: Id409899bf04e7f9f2653e6c48cfebd0a92ca2d08
'}, {'created': '2018-12-07 09:50:19.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Reload haproxy when certificate is renewed

This changes the internal certificates that are requested for HAProxy to
use several SubjectAltNames instead of using several certificates as
used to be the case. This makes it easier for certmonger to interface
with HAProxy, as only one renewal is needed, which will just trigger one
post-save command.

This also adds an explicit post-save command that was introduced in the
patch this depends on.

Preferably this patch should merge at the same time as the one this
depends on.

Note that this still needs to change the way that manifests/haproxy.pp
and manifests/haproxy/endpoint.pp read the internal certificates to take
into use the one certificate as opposed to one per network. So this
needs to be changed in puppet-tripleo.

Depends-On: I5d91f8d9b5cd4f86ae0511a69e58858c5dccd35d
Change-Id: Id409899bf04e7f9f2653e6c48cfebd0a92ca2d08
'}, {'created': '2019-01-11 13:06:13.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Reload haproxy when certificate is renewed

commit_message:
Reload haproxy when certificate is renewed

This adds an explicit post-save command that was introduced in the
patch this depends on.

Preferably this patch should merge at the same time as the one this
depends on.

Related-Bug: #1811401

[{'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-12-06 23:47:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8871, 'date': '2018-12-07 04:04:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I noticed Zuul failed, I think you hit bug(s):

'}, {'created': '2018-12-07 09:44:32.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Reload HAProxy when certificate is renewed

This is meant to fix the issue of the certificate renewal not
automatically restarting/reloading the haproxy service. This assumes
that only one certificate is needed for the internal network, which is
something that the patch this depends on introduces.

It's all done by a script that's installed by puppet.

Needed-By: Id409899bf04e7f9f2653e6c48cfebd0a92ca2d08
Change-Id: I5d91f8d9b5cd4f86ae0511a69e58858c5dccd35d
"}, {'created': '2018-12-07 09:46:26.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Reload HAProxy when certificate is renewed

This is meant to fix the issue of the certificate renewal not
automatically restarting/reloading the haproxy service. This assumes
that only one certificate is needed for the internal network, which is
something that the patch this depends on introduces.

It's all done by a script that's installed by puppet.

Note that this still needs to change the way that manifests/haproxy.pp
and manifests/haproxy/endpoint.pp read the internal certificates to take
into use the one certificate as opposed to one per network.

commit_message:
Reload HAProxy when certificate is renewed

This is meant to fix the issue of the certificate renewal not
automatically restarting/reloading the haproxy service.

It's all done by a script that's installed by puppet.

Preferably this patch and the one pointed by this should merge at the
same time.

Co-Authored-By: Grzegorz Grasza <xek@redhat.com>
Needed-By: Id409899bf04e7f9f2653e6c48cfebd0a92ca2d08
Change-Id: I5d91f8d9b5cd4f86ae0511a69e58858c5dccd35d

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-27 22:13:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

So, I guess this is should be marked as a WIP since:

1. We need to figure out what the name of the rule needs to be since it's used by both create and resize (can we just remove 'create' from the name and have it be compute:servers:cell_down and let the description explain what it's used for?)

2. I don't think we need to try and bend over backward to move this into the REST API controller code because that's going to likely be a lot more work than it's worth given where we need to use this. This isn't the only policy rule like that, see network:attach_external_network.

3. We don't know if we're going to add this policy rule at all because of Mel's spec to count qouta from placement: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/509042/"}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2018-11-28 12:32:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Workflow-1

> So, I guess this is should be marked as a WIP since:
 > 
 > 1. We need to figure out what the name of the rule needs to be
 > since it's used by both create and resize (can we just remove
 > 'create' from the name and have it be compute:servers:cell_down and
 > let the description explain what it's used for?)
 > 
 > 2. I don't think we need to try and bend over backward to move this
 > into the REST API controller code because that's going to likely be
 > a lot more work than it's worth given where we need to use this.
 > This isn't the only policy rule like that, see network:attach_external_network.
 > 
 > 3. We don't know if we're going to add this policy rule at all
 > because of Mel's spec to count qouta from placement:
 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/509042/

agreed."}, {'account_id': 26936, 'date': '2019-01-28 18:33:56.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

In favor of Mel's spec to count quotas from placement:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/509042/"}]

commit_message:
Add os_compute_api:servers:create:cell_down policy

A new policy called ``os_compute_api:servers:create:cell_down`` is
added which will allow only admins by default to be able to create
instances even if there are active instances in down cells for
which quota calculation would be partially incorrect as down cells
would be skipped. If deplyoments wish to allow users to be able
to bypass this quota mis-calculation and let users create instances
they can change the rule's value from admin only.

Related to blueprint handling-down-cell

Change-Id: Ifa7df0c6b9d0042f51c0e9fc27a946870f780a44

commit_message:
CI: Remove ovsdbapp-src tempest job definition

This playbook has been already migrated to the ovsdbapp repository as
part of the commit https://review.openstack.org/#/c/604102. There is no
reason/need to also keep it in the networking-ovn repository since it's not
used anywhere.

Change-Id: I6ba8f2ee1c20b27a8e0c15fe651d5278eca99ff2
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Support Keystone AuthN and AuthZ for k8s

Now cloud-provider-openstack of Kubernetes has a webhook to support
Keystone authorization and authentication. With this feature, user
can use a new label 'keystone-auth-enabled' to enable the keystone
authN and authZ.

DocImpact
Task: 21637
Story: 1755770

Change-Id: I3d21ad8f55c0d7308a302f62db9e9af147a604f8

commit_message:
Unpin puppet gem version selection

The tickets PUP-9270 [1] and PUP-9271 [2]
is fixed and we should unpin so we use the
latest puppet 5.5 version.

Also changes so that we check that the
templated var puppet_gem_version is actually
containing a value and not just empty if so
we can skip setting the environment variable
and just have the gem unpinned in the spec
helper.

[1] https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/PUP-9270
[2] https://tickets.puppetlabs.com/browse/MODULES-8193

Change-Id: I9b0dbc704638097fc0f6e3702fcea04fb8541b02

commit_message:
Fix missing print format error

Missing print format will cause 'ValueError: unsupported
format character' error, this is to fix it.

Change-Id: I6f098f103c0eda4ede931d6bfa4901e1dea14b15

commit_message:
Use local config for placement-status CLI

In commit 6fa9eabb79753f0a77a26eac1035edeb58e3c16d, we decided not to
use global the default global cfg.CONF that oslo_config provides and
later documented the guideline in doc/source/contributor/goals.rst.

This patch changes the placement-status CLI path according to that
guideline.

Change-Id: I2eea00343d1bbdf486985daeaf6707358b6a2708

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-20 09:45:13.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Handle image download and conversion errors

Provide message when there is not enough space for image conversion

When booting a VM instance with block device mapping, two steps follow
to create the volume:

1. image is downloaded to /opt/img-conversions/cinder
2. image is converted to raw in the same location

The problem found is that only step 2 is raising an error if not enough
space is available at '/opt/img-conversions/'. This fix is also raising
an error to handle download error at step 1. The error message proposed
is: "Error creating volume. Failed to create volume from image.
Insufficient free space on /opt/img-conversions for download and
conversion". This error will be displayed in the volume metadata and in
cinder-volume.log.

Change-Id: I56057475cf55e4be77bbd1dfeabf2bf20d3e1311
Co-authored-by: Irina Mihai <irina.mihai@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-11-24 06:57:00.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Handle image download and conversion errors

The problem found is that only step 2 is raising an error if not enough
space is available at '/opt/img-conversions/'. This fix is also raising
an error to handle download error at step 1. The error message proposed
is: "Error creating volume. Failed to create volume from image.
Insufficient free space on /opt/img-conversions for download and
conversion". This error will be displayed in the volume metadata and in
cinder-volume.log.

Change-Id: I56057475cf55e4be77bbd1dfeabf2bf20d3e1311
Co-authored-by: Irina Mihai <irina.mihai@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-11-28 13:44:36.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Handle image download and conversion errors

Provide message when there is not enough space for image conversion

With rbd as cinder backend, when creating volume from image, two steps
follow to create the volume:

1. image is downloaded to image_conversion_dir
2. image is converted to raw in the same location

The problem found is that only step 2 is raising an error if not enough
space is available at image_conversion_dir. This fix is also raising an
error to handle download error at step 1. The error message proposed is:
"Error creating volume. Failed to create volume from image.
Insufficient free space on image_conversion_dir for download and
conversion". This error will be displayed in the volume metadata and in
cinder-volume.log.

Change-Id: I56057475cf55e4be77bbd1dfeabf2bf20d3e1311
Co-authored-by: Irina Mihai <irina.mihai@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-12-01 16:17:35.000000000', 'message': 'Handle image download and conversion errors

Provide message when there is not enough space for image conversion

With rbd as cinder backend, when creating volume from image, two steps
follow to create the volume:

1. image is downloaded to image_conversion_dir
2. image is converted to raw in the same location

If no space left in image_conversion_dir happened in step1, function
fetch() in image_utils.py will catch this (IOError with e.errno ==
errno.ENOSPC), and exception.ImageTooBig will be re-raised. But if
happened in step 2, no "space" specific exception will be raised in
current code. This patch provided the space specific exception
InsufficientConversionSpace to indicate no space.

Change-Id: I56057475cf55e4be77bbd1dfeabf2bf20d3e1311
Co-authored-by: Irina Mihai <irina.mihai@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-12-13 06:39:42.000000000', 'message': 'Handle image download and conversion errors

2. image is converted to raw in the same location

If no space left in image_conversion_dir happened in step1, function
fetch() in image_utils.py will catch this (IOError with e.errno ==
errno.ENOSPC), and exception.ImageTooBig will be re-raised. If happened
in step 2, no "space" specific message will be logged in current code.
This patch provided the space specific log to indicate no space.

Change-Id: I56057475cf55e4be77bbd1dfeabf2bf20d3e1311
Co-authored-by: Irina Mihai <irina.mihai@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Handle image download and conversion errors

Provide message when there is not enough space for image conversion

With rbd as cinder backend, when creating volume from image, two steps
follow to create the volume:

1. image is downloaded to image_conversion_dir
2. image is converted to raw in the same location

If no space left in image_conversion_dir happened in step1, function
fetch() in image_utils.py will catch this (IOError with e.errno ==
errno.ENOSPC), and exception.ImageTooBig will be re-raised. If happened
in step 2, no "space" specific message will be logged in current code.
This patch provided the space specific log to indicate no space.

Change-Id: I56057475cf55e4be77bbd1dfeabf2bf20d3e1311
Co-authored-by: Irina Mihai <irina.mihai@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>

subject: Service cleanup should be optional
messages:
[{'account_id': 21302, 'date': '2019-01-17 09:47:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-01-17 09:53:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Can you please explain why?'}, {'account_id': 21302, 'date': '2019-01-17 10:02:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Can you please explain why?

We need it for the test that makes sure that LB is created and removed when the service is created and removed.
So the removal of the service should be done as a part of the test and not as a cleanup process'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-01-17 10:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > Can you please explain why?
 > 
 > We need it for the test that makes sure that LB is created and
 > removed when the service is created and removed.
 > So the removal of the service should be done as a part of the test
 > and not as a cleanup process

But, if you remove the service and check if it exists or not on the test, that checking will happen before the cleanup function takes in, right?'}, {'account_id': 4727, 'date': '2019-01-17 10:45:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

@Luis, If I understand correctly - If you don't remove the cleanup and delete the resource the cleanup will fail at treadown"}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-01-17 11:24:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-23 15:53:16.000000000', 'message': "overcloud-agent: create ansible-playbook symlink in post-install

overcloud-agent element takes care of deploying the heat-agents that
depend on Ansible.

In RHEL8, we'll have /usr/bin/ansible-playbook provided by ansible package.
Everywhere in TripleO we rely on /usr/bin/ansible-playbook but the
ansible-python3 package in Fedora 28 doesn't provide it.

Until it does, we have a temporary workaround that will create a symlink only
if the file doesn't exist and if ansible-playbook3 is here.

Change-Id: Iad05160afb700a18caf5d3584c2826857412a3fa
Related-Bug: #1812837
"}, {'created': '2019-01-25 13:41:24.000000000', 'message': 'overcloud-agent: create ansible-playbook symlinks in post-install

overcloud-agent element takes care of deploying the heat-agents that
depend on Ansible.

This temporary workaround makes sure:
- ansible-playbook exists if ansible-playbook-3 only is installed (f28)
- ansible-playbook-3 exists if ansible-playbook only is installed (el8)

Change-Id: Iad05160afb700a18caf5d3584c2826857412a3fa
Related-Bug: #1812837
'}, {'created': '2019-01-25 13:44:06.000000000', 'message': 'overcloud-agent: create ansible-playbook symlinks in post-install

depend on Ansible.

Change-Id: Iad05160afb700a18caf5d3584c2826857412a3fa
Related-Bug: #1812837
'}]
commit_message:
overcloud-agent: create ansible-playbook symlinks in post-install

overcloud-agent element takes care of deploying the heat-agents that
depend on Ansible.

This temporary workaround makes sure:
- ansible-playbook exists if ansible-playbook-3 only is installed (f28)
- ansible-playbook-3 exists if ansible-playbook only is installed (el8)

Change-Id: Iad05160afb700a18caf5d3584c2826857412a3fa
Related-Bug: #1812837

subject: Fixes for Unicode characters in python 2 requests
messages: [{'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2019-01-28 10:18:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2019-01-28 11:30:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-01-28 15:33:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-28 10:18:24.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes for Unicode characters in python 2 requests

urljoin() util function uses str() which will trigger an exception on
Unicode characters in python 2, use string type from six to support both
versions

Furthermore, HttpException would trigger an exception when logging an
error, as __unicode__() may call super().__str__() with Unicode
characters. Replace the call with similar code (returning the message)

Sample command to trigger both errors in current code:
openstack port delete does_not_exist‚Ñ¢

Change-Id: Iedc47fa74e89f70e6f5e846f8a564bf1db40228a
Story: 2004356
Task: 29066
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes for Unicode characters in python 2 requests

urljoin() util function uses str() which will trigger an exception on
Unicode characters in python 2, use string type from six to support both
versions

Furthermore, HttpException would trigger an exception when logging an
error, as __unicode__() may call super().__str__() with Unicode
characters. Replace the call with similar code (returning the message)

Sample command to trigger both errors in current code:
openstack port delete does_not_exist‚Ñ¢

Change-Id: Iedc47fa74e89f70e6f5e846f8a564bf1db40228a
Story: 2004356
Task: 29066

commit_message:
Improve error message around hieradata override file

If the file specified is empty, we currently throw a generic message
about it not being in the correct format. Let's add a check to make sure
the file is not empty before attempting to parse it as yaml.

Change-Id: I702da1170484c0d10c3ae836ec3f7550975a341c
Closes-Bug: #1810436

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-11 05:00:49.000000000', 'message': 'Add python3.5 support for monasca-analytics

This patch implements followings for py35 support using six(er) and 2to3.

- Python 3 map/filter returns iterator, must be converted to list
- use six.string_types instead of basestring
- use six.iteritems instead of iteritems
- use six.moves for using cPickle and SocketServer packages
- use six.assertCountEqual instead of assertItemsEqual
- remove relative imports
- update BytecodeAssembler(monasca_analytics/
  banana/bytecode/assembler.py) for python3

Can be tested with:
  tox -e py35

Change-Id: If1b92d0ffc56492950f6a02ebdbe1596d0dce368
'}, {'created': '2019-01-10 07:09:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add python3.5 support for monasca-analytics

- use six.string_types instead of basestring
- use six.iteritems instead of iteritems

- use six.assertCountEqual instead of assertItemsEqual
- remove relative imports
- update BytecodeAssembler(monasca_analytics/

Can be tested with:

- remove relative imports
- update BytecodeAssembler(monasca_analytics/
  banana/bytecode/assembler.py) for python3

Can be tested with:
  tox -e py35

Change-Id: If1b92d0ffc56492950f6a02ebdbe1596d0dce368
'}]
commit_message:
Support python3.5 for monasca-analytics

This patch implements followings for py35 support using six(er) and 2to3.

- Python 3 map/filter returns iterator, must be converted to list
- use six.string_types instead of basestring
- use six.iteritems instead of iteritems
- use six.moves for using cPickle and SocketServer packages
- use six.assertCountEqual instead of assertItemsEqual
- remove relative imports
- update BytecodeAssembler(monasca_analytics/
  banana/bytecode/assembler.py) for python3

Can be tested with:
  tox -e py35

Change-Id: If1b92d0ffc56492950f6a02ebdbe1596d0dce368

commit_message:
Cloud Vision: clarify meaning of design goals

Feedback on this section from a couple of different sources reveals that
the current description fails to make clear that the design goals
represent capabilities that we want OpenStack to present to
applications, and aren't necessarily descriptive of the OpenStack
service implementations themselves. Tweak the wording to help readers
interpret the goals in the correct context.

Change-Id: I5e2fe12dca016f0e9039cdf4290060ed51bc10ce

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-28 14:33:15.000000000', 'message': 'Fix broken OpenStack pkg version check

The current OpenStack version check uses a package which does not
have semantic versioning and is not listed on the dict of package
version in charmhelpers. This change fixes this by using a package
which does have semantic versioning and is in the dict of versions.
If no package is installed which fit these requirements then
os_release is relied on to fallback to another method (checking
openstack-origin).

Change-Id: I256b2782e83e2619108726eeb27505d5f1854284
Closes-Bug: #1741628
'}]
commit_message:
Fix broken OpenStack pkg version check

The current OpenStack version check uses a package which does not
have semantic versioning and is not listed on the dict of package
version in charmhelpers. This change fixes this by using a package
which does have semantic versioning and is in the dict of versions.
If no package is installed which fit these requirements then
os_release is relied on to fallback to another method (checking
openstack-origin).

Change-Id: I256b2782e83e2619108726eeb27505d5f1854284
Closes-Bug: #1741628

tree.

messages:
[{'account_id': 29543, 'date': '2019-01-22 14:33:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-01-22 14:33:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-01-22 14:52:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Add support for Infoblox in Designate role

This change adds support for Infoblox as a backend for Designate.

Change-Id: I7ae038befa88f5a1b3a1187a0e9037ed30f94b17

commit_message:
Ensure NP changes are applied to services

When a Network Policy is changed, services must also be updated,
deleting the unnecessary rules that do not match the NP anymore
and create needed ones.

Closes-Bug: #1811242

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

Change-Id: I800477d08fd1f46c2a94d3653496f8f1188a3844

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-24 22:22:02.000000000', 'message': 'Change L3 agent to log message after failure

If the L3 agent fails to send its report_state
to the server, it logs an exception:

   Failed reporting state!: MessagingTimeout: Timed out...

If it then tries a second time and succeeds it just
goes on happily. It would be nice if it logged that
it had success on the subsequent attempt so someone
looking at the logs know it recovered.

Change-Id: I9019782588caffcb647cf1fd557f76ce89cea254
'}]
commit_message:
Change L3 agent to log message after failure

If the L3 agent fails to send its report_state
to the server, it logs an exception:

   Failed reporting state!: MessagingTimeout: Timed out...

If it then tries a second time and succeeds it just
goes on happily. It would be nice if it logged that
it had success on the subsequent attempt so someone
looking at the logs know it recovered.

Change-Id: I9019782588caffcb647cf1fd557f76ce89cea254

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-19 19:45:56.000000000', 'message': "WIP Compute location properly in server

The shade layer pulls the az and project_id info out of the server
record and feeds it into the location field. This is because the
location field should be where the resource is, and the existing token
should only be a fallback.

This isn't happening in the resource layer, so start doing that.

As a result of digging, make sure we always pass in the connection
object to the Resources when we make them. And stop creating a bare
resource in order to use the 'new' class method. It's a class method, we
don't need to instantiate.

This patch, once done, will cause carnage in the unittests, because of
the bajillion unittests that are testing constructor parameters instead
of testing behavior. We were avoiding that earlier, but it's time to
start cleaning this stuff up.

Change-Id: Ic8850cd2863e2c806464b92cde2c749f6cc01a91

commit_message:
Compute location properly in server

The shade layer pulls the az and project_id info out of the server
record and feeds it into the location field. This is because the
location field should be where the resource is, and the existing token
should only be a fallback.

This isn't happening in the resource layer, so start doing that.

As a result of digging, make sure we always pass in the connection
object to the Resources when we make them. And stop creating a bare
resource in order to use the 'new' class method. It's a class method, we
don't need to instantiate.

Change-Id: Ic8850cd2863e2c806464b92cde2c749f6cc01a91

commit_message:
Ensure we get the file directly in the container

This measure might help avoiding the folowing infamous podman error:
standard_init_linux.go:203: exec user process caused \"no such file or directory\"

Making a static copy inside the container of the docker-puppet.sh script will
avoid any I/O or race issues, and allow the deploy to occurs as expected.

Context: https://github.com/containers/libpod/issues/1844
Change-Id: Iaa09f01184fea05e839efa813104a7b783e6681e

Change-Id: Id0f39e3253b1486db8ae2da3d7dc6c0fdb41062a
"}, {'created': '2018-10-04 13:00:31.000000000', 'message': "Properly pass the CA to requests

commit_message:
Properly pass the CA to requests

We store the CA in request.cert, but it's not compatible with a cert. To
pass the CA to requests, we need to set the verify argument.

Change-Id: Id0f39e3253b1486db8ae2da3d7dc6c0fdb41062a

commit_message:
WIP: Deploy a Docker registry in CI

Currently only doing this in the seed job, since that is where a
registry makes most sense.

For a (future) multinode overcloud job, we may wish to deploy a registry
on one of the controllers.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/631859
Change-Id: I873daaaad79002196cc380390c785dd1b6b0a3ac

This patch ensures that the lb sg rules that are no longer
needed (not allowed anymore by the NP) are removed, i.e., if an
existing rule at the loadbalancer is no longer enabled by any of
the NP applied to the svc, then it will be removed to ensure the
specific traffic is not allowed.

commit_message:
Ensure lb sg rules are deleted when no longer allowed

This patch ensures that the lb sg rules that are no longer
needed (not allowed anymore by the NP) are removed, i.e., if an
existing rule at the loadbalancer is no longer enabled by any of
the NP applied to the svc, then it will be removed to ensure the
specific traffic is not allowed.

Partially Implements: blueprint k8s-network-policies

Change-Id: I39a84a47a821cdd6ae92ce53f39106e8b6abe98e

[{'created': '2018-11-21 14:39:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix logging for metrics_qdr

- metrics_qdr logs in debug mode which makes it the log file to grow quickly
- current log file path does not match with the path fluentd is tailing
- current log file patch conflicts with general purpose QDR composable service

This patch fixes all avove mentioned issues.

Resolves-Bug: #1804464

commit_message:
Fix logging for metrics_qdr

- metrics_qdr logs in debug mode which makes it the log file to grow quickly
- current log file path does not match with the path fluentd is tailing
- current log file patch conflicts with general purpose QDR composable service

This patch fixes all avove mentioned issues.

Change-Id: I69e0cf06d96389201258e8fb2f112aec15f64013
Resolves-Bug: #1804464

commit_message:
docker-puppet.py: used dedicated hiera entry, not uuid

Currently it is not possible to do per-node customization inside
docker-puppet.py because it overrides the fact 'uuid'.

This change adds a dedicated docker_puppet entry in hiera.yaml so that
docker-puppet.py needs to do nothing special for
/etc/puppet/hieradata/docker_puppet.json to be included in the hiera
merge.

Conflicts:
        docker/docker-puppet.py
Change-Id: Icf37dcd63e0152ee15e9f0079b45e31a4f8d9fbb
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/607635/
Closes-Bug: #1761624
(cherry picked from commit 6bbc3b51dfa6c9ea744dbb7b6212db7c56e8d827)
(cherry picked from commit e39c57b02ca593f6bf7313aa13ff5fbacbae8536)

subject: Prevent triggering firewall actions while configuring HA services
messages: [{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-01-28 14:02:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/queens.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-01-28 14:05:08.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned\n\nnot needed in fact, pike backports aren't supported anymore."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-28 14:02:43.000000000', 'message': "Prevent triggering firewall actions while configuring HA services

When a fence_xvm stonith device is configured, puppet module fence_xvm creates
firewall rules to configure this fencing device.

When transient containers *_init_bundle run at step 5 or above, fence_xvm will
end up calling iptables, which is forbidden from such containers.

We can't noop the firewall resources like we did in [1], because fence_xvm
makes use of specific providers for some resources [2]. So instead, we do not
include module fence_xvm when running from a container. This is safe
because the firewall rules needed for the fencing configuration are still
created when puppet is executed on the host at step 5. (Besides, only that
fencing device requires firewall rules)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/docker/services/pacemaker/haproxy.yaml#L160
[2] e.g. https://github.com/openstack/puppet-pacemaker/blob/master/manifests/stonith/fence_xvm.pp#L237

Change-Id: I595f8bc22e76868b7dace400667d53f3c4565248
Related: rhbz#1598904
(cherry picked from commit 907853e35f160d6f39d65e354870ac217f3e4b12)
(cherry picked from commit cae8cd60d1121f7fccd813f1b42ecf823f128b3e)
"}]
commit_message:
Prevent triggering firewall actions while configuring HA services

When a fence_xvm stonith device is configured, puppet module fence_xvm creates
firewall rules to configure this fencing device.

When transient containers *_init_bundle run at step 5 or above, fence_xvm will
end up calling iptables, which is forbidden from such containers.

We can't noop the firewall resources like we did in [1], because fence_xvm
makes use of specific providers for some resources [2]. So instead, we do not
include module fence_xvm when running from a container. This is safe
because the firewall rules needed for the fencing configuration are still
created when puppet is executed on the host at step 5. (Besides, only that
fencing device requires firewall rules)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/docker/services/pacemaker/haproxy.yaml#L160
[2] e.g. https://github.com/openstack/puppet-pacemaker/blob/master/manifests/stonith/fence_xvm.pp#L237

Change-Id: I595f8bc22e76868b7dace400667d53f3c4565248
Related: rhbz#1598904
(cherry picked from commit 907853e35f160d6f39d65e354870ac217f3e4b12)
(cherry picked from commit cae8cd60d1121f7fccd813f1b42ecf823f128b3e)

[{'created': '2018-10-03 16:30:06.000000000', 'message': "Prevent triggering firewall actions while configuring HA services

When a fence_xvm stonith device is configured, puppet module fence_xvm creates
firewall rules to configure this fencing device.

When transient containers *_init_bundle run at step 5 or above, fence_xvm will
end up calling iptables, which is forbidden from such containers.

We can't noop the firewall resources like we did in [1], because fence_xvm
makes use of specific providers for some resources [2]. So instead, we do not
include module fence_xvm when running from a container. This is safe
because the firewall rules needed for the fencing configuration are still
created when puppet is executed on the host at step 5. (Besides, only that
fencing device requires firewall rules)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/docker/services/pacemaker/haproxy.yaml#L160
[2] e.g. https://github.com/openstack/puppet-pacemaker/blob/master/manifests/stonith/fence_xvm.pp#L237

Change-Id: I595f8bc22e76868b7dace400667d53f3c4565248
Related: rhbz#1598904
(cherry picked from commit 907853e35f160d6f39d65e354870ac217f3e4b12)
"}]
commit_message:
Prevent triggering firewall actions while configuring HA services

When a fence_xvm stonith device is configured, puppet module fence_xvm creates
firewall rules to configure this fencing device.

When transient containers *_init_bundle run at step 5 or above, fence_xvm will
end up calling iptables, which is forbidden from such containers.

We can't noop the firewall resources like we did in [1], because fence_xvm
makes use of specific providers for some resources [2]. So instead, we do not
include module fence_xvm when running from a container. This is safe
because the firewall rules needed for the fencing configuration are still
created when puppet is executed on the host at step 5. (Besides, only that
fencing device requires firewall rules)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/docker/services/pacemaker/haproxy.yaml#L160
[2] e.g. https://github.com/openstack/puppet-pacemaker/blob/master/manifests/stonith/fence_xvm.pp#L237

Change-Id: I595f8bc22e76868b7dace400667d53f3c4565248
Related: rhbz#1598904
(cherry picked from commit 907853e35f160d6f39d65e354870ac217f3e4b12)

commit_message:
remove the neutron.db._model_query module

The functionality from model_query is already in neutron-lib and
consumers are using it. This patch removes the _model_query module
from neutron and updates all imports to use neutron-lib's version of
it instead.

NeutronLibImpact

subject: Add specs for tacker-service-function-forwarding-group
messages:
[{'account_id': 29809, 'date': '2019-01-28 07:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-01-28 07:39:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 29809, 'date': '2019-01-28 12:53:35.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
